group_1.narration: I went to visit my mom and dad's graves@for the first time in years.
I had a sliver of hope…@that if I chanted a sutra and paid respects,@I'd be able to think clearly.
I wish I could hear Mom's voice from the afterlife…@but my chances are pretty slim.
…Well, I guess I don't remember a whole lot…@about what Mom's voice sounded like anyway…

group_1.textCenter: Did you think of yourself as one, too?
Did you die a hero?@Were you satisfied when you passed on?
Or were you more like that girl who jumped in the river…?
…She ain't gonna be able to tell me anything…
I thought…it'd be nice if she could hear me.
S'pose it didn't work out that way, though.

group_1.textRight: How unusual…Ryouko…
…Was there something you wanted to ask your mother…?
…Whatever the reason,@you inspired me to come visit her grave too.
So let's pay our respects together.
Actually, I haven't thanked you properly yet…
For Suitoku Temple.
You're the one who saved it, aren't you…?
The timing was too convenient… I always suspected@that it could've been a Diviner's doing.
I never imagined that it would've been my own granddaughter, though.

group_1.narration: You're right, Gramps.@I made a wish and became a Magical Girl@to save Suitoku Temple.
Back then, the temple and the surrounding land@were bein' used as toys by corrupt officials and politicians.@The place had to be evicted.
Us and…Jouan Temple were crazy busy,@so I didn't catch a lot of the details,@but I had an idea.
Then Kyubey showed up,@so I made a wish.
I said…@"I want you to expose the corruption@of those trying to bring down Suitoku Temple."

group_1.textRight: Their demands were unreasonable,@they had institutional law on their side.
So Suitoku Temple had no choice but to give up.

group_1.textLeft: …And then the mastermind behind the wrongdoing@was brought to light.
I guess that'd look pretty suspicious, huh?

group_1.textRight: …But why'd you save it?
Suitoku Temple was just a relative's temple to you.
It's your base in Kamihama now, but we only visited@it a handful of times back in the day.
You used your once-in-a-lifetime miracle@to fight to save the temple…
That sort of thing's not an easy choice to make…@Why'd you do it?

group_1.textLeft: The heck…? I don't even know why you're askin'…

group_1.narration: There was somethin' evil right in front of me@that was makin' others unhappy,@and I was the only one who could stop it.@It's only natural that I'd use that power, right?
There was no other choice for me.

group_1.textLeft: Because I couldn't just let that slide…

group_1.textRight: …Is that really all?

group_1.textLeft: I mighta just been…pretty pissed off.

group_1.textRight: Pissed off…?

group_1.narration: The guys pushin' for the development@of the area around Suitoku Temple@had the media heraldin' them as heroes@boostin' the economy.
And y'know, they could've been doin' something@that would benefit a bunch of folks.
But there were a lot of people who lost out, too…

group_1.textLeft: That's why I was hopin' to expose the corrupt people involved.

group_1.textRight: Was that really unforgivable?

group_1.textLeft: They were hailed as great saviors, but behind the scenes, they were makin' people cry.

group_1.narration: It reminded me of…@me and my mom.
I heard Mom was a hero who saved people's lives,@but in light of that, I had a tough childhood.
When I found out about the crisis at Suitoku Temple,@I think I put myself in that situation.

group_1.textRight: I see what you mean…@I get it now.
Come.
There's something you should hear.
I want you to know how your mother died…
Or, rather,@I want you to know…how she lived.
